article.headline: How to save money in tough times: 6 doâs and donâts
article.body: This article is reprinted by permission from NerdWallet. Probably the last thing you want to think about during a crisis is working on healthy financial habits like saving money. But if youâre able to save, you can make your eventual recovery easier. âEvery time you put some [money] away, youâre looking out for your future self,â says Saundra Davis, founder and executive director at Sage Financial Solutions, a San Francisco Bay Area-based nonprofit that offers financial coach training and services to people across the wealth spectrum. Whether or not your financial situation has changed since the start of 2020, you may benefit from these saving strategies now or down the road.Do: Reduce costs, including bills if needed Common advice to save money is to cut unnecessary costs. During a continuing crisis such as a pandemic, you might need to redefine what is âunnecessary.â Be sure to read: Making sense of the new July 15 deadline for filing â and paying â your taxes Start with the cost of bare essentials to operate your household â rent or mortgage, utilities, food â and when you factor bills in, donât treat them all the same. For example, paying your credit card bill in full every month is normally the best tactic, but in hard times, itâs OK not to follow this rule and just pay the minimum. For loan payments, see if your creditor can offer relief. âDonât have your lender deciding what you can pay,â Davis says. âSketch out your own budget.â This might mean working with your lender to reduce payments or suspend them temporarily.Do: Adjust your savings goals Having a dollar amount to save up to is generally helpful. AnÂ emergency fund, for example, is a standard goal that involves building up three to six monthsâ worth of living expenses. But during an emergency, consider resetting expectations. Also see: Hereâs how many Americans are able to save their stimulus checks âIf your income changes, you arenât beholden to saving a fixed amount,â says LaKhaun McKinley, certified financial planner and owner of the firm MNM Vested in Katy, Texas. The way you save might need to be tweaked, too. If you use automatic transfers from checking to savings accounts, see if that amount is still doable for you. If not, reduce the amount. Or, as a last resort, cancel the transfers for now and make one-off transfers when possible. When saving money, âthe habit is more important than the amount,â Davis says.Do: Find a high savings rate Opening aÂ high-yield savings accountÂ at an online bank is a good strategy, regardless of the economic environment. The national average rate is 0.06%, but some online savings accounts are currently offering over 1% annual percentage yield. The account-opening process can take a few minutes. Opening a high-yield account âcan be such a simple way to earn more,â says Kelley Long. Sheâs a Chicago-based certified public accountant, financial planner and member of the American Institute of CPAsâ Consumer Financial Education Advocates.Do: Get help from your community to save costs If youâre experiencing financial hardship, call 2-1-1 or visit the website 211.org. This is a free way to learn about resources in your community, including food banks, meal services for seniors and students, shelters, mental health services and more. If youâve never asked for help like this before, it may feel uncomfortable. But accepting meals or other support can be an important lifeline as well as help you save money. Also see: How bad is it if I withdraw from my 401(k) during the pandemic? âWe want to stay aware of whatâs available in our community and give ourselves the emotional room to do things weâve never done before,â Davis says. Some relief is nationwide, includingÂ postponed federal student loan paymentsÂ andÂ coronavirus-specific unemployment programs, but your local community might have additional resources.Donât: Dip into savings without a plan If you have an emergency fund and you need it now, use it. But estimate the amount you need before withdrawing, and keep tabs on how you spend it. Youâll eventually need to save up again, and you want to make that process manageable. It might help to settle on a minimum amount you need to keep in a savings account to feel OK. âEveryone has a different feeling [for] what would give them that security,â Long says. For some people, for example, âseeing a comma in your account can have a formative effect on your feeling of financial security.âDonât: Withdraw from savings too often Keep an eye on the frequency with which you turn to your savings account. Banks can charge an excessive savings withdrawal fee if you go over six a month. During COVID-19, the Federal Reserve has paused this rule, but itâs up to each bank to choose whether to charge the fee. Watch out for other fees, too, such as for overdrawing if you dip past your checking account balance. See: The best side gigs you can do from home If youâre running into trouble with fees, examine why you needed more savings than expected. âWe might be overaggressive in savings goals. Thatâs usually due to failing to account for certain expenses in our spending plan,â Long says. âIn a crisis,â she adds, âwe need to remember that there are times that we canât be long-term in our thinking.âMore from NerdWallet: Cash Accounts and Apps to Buddy Up With Your Investments How to Bank When You Canât Go to the Bank 3 Ways to Skip Your Bankâs Long Phone Lines Spencer Tierney is a writer at NerdWallet.
